question: Is France right to intervene in Mali?

content.source_1: United Nations Security Council Resolution 2085 (20 Dec 2012) — Authorized the deployment of an African-led force (AFISMA) and called on member states to assist Mali in restoring territorial integrity and protecting civilians, providing international legal backing for external military support to Mali.
content.source_2: BBC News, “Mali conflict: French-led troops take Timbuktu” (28 Jan 2013) — Reported that French and Malian forces rapidly retook Gao and Timbuktu and halted jihadist advances toward Bamako, preventing a likely collapse of the Malian state in early 2013.
content.source_3: Reuters, “France says its forces killed al Qaeda’s North Africa chief in Mali” (5 Jun 2020) — Documented the French military’s killing of AQIM leader Abdelmalek Droukdel, highlighting concrete counterterrorism gains with regional and global security implications.
content.source_4: MINUSMA Human Rights and Protection Division, “Report of the fact-finding mission on the incident in Bounty on 3 January 2021” (30 Mar 2021) — Concluded a French airstrike struck a wedding gathering, killing 19 civilians, raising serious concerns about civilian harm and the legitimacy of the intervention’s conduct.
content.source_5: Reuters, “France completes withdrawal of troops from Mali” (17 Aug 2022) — Noted France’s exit amid deteriorating relations with Mali’s junta and rising anti-French sentiment, suggesting the intervention became politically untenable and potentially counterproductive for Mali’s sovereignty and stability.
content.source_6: The Guardian (Opinion), Seumas Milne, “This is a war to reassert French power in Africa” (16 Jan 2013) — Argued the intervention was driven by geopolitical and resource interests rather than humanitarian necessity, framing it as a neo-colonial assertion of French influence.
